dsls.content1: Here are three sentences. Which of the templates below correctly abstracts so that all three match the same pattern as the template?

questions.text:
Seattle is a big city.  
Eugene is a medium city  
Hillview is a small city.

dsls.title: Multiple Choice

dsls.content1: Each of these vehicles has been decomposed into smaller pieces. Match each vehicle with its decomposed list.
dsls.title: Matching

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions:
Get the zombie to the sunflower using as few blocks as you can.\
(Avoid the chompers!)

Now we have a new block called `repeat until`.\
This will let us keep looping commands until the zombie gets the sunflower.  

Use the new `repeat until` block to solve this puzzle in as few commands as possible.
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
Now we have a new block called `repeat until`.\

Use the new `repeat until` block to solve this puzzle in as few commands as possible.

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions: This rectangular flower bed has a perimeter of 600. The long side has a length of 200. Draw the rectangle using as few blocks as possible.
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
This rectangular flower bed has a perimeter of 600.\
The long side has a length of 200. 

Draw the rectangle using as few blocks as possible.

authored_hints.4-5_Artist_3_a:
If the flower bed is 600 pixels around and two of the sides are 200 pixels long, here is how to figure out what the short sides add up to:

**600 - 200 - 200 = 200**

That means both short sides add up to 200 pixels.

**What is 200 / 2?**
authored_hints.4-5_Artist_3_b: If you can't see where the `repeat` loop goes right away, try coding out the whole solution and look for a pattern.

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
Try to figure out what happens if you run this code (or just press "Run" and try it). 

Next, repeat the code enough times to complete the drawing!

Loop the blocks to create a circle of colors.

authored_hints.4-5_Artist_4_a:
There are 360 degrees in a circle! 

That's how many times you need to repeat this code (turning 1 degree at a time) before the circle is done!

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions:
The halfway line on a soccer field is perpendicular to the sidelines.\
This rectangle has a perimeter of 800 pixels total, and it is 240 pixels long. How tall is it?   

Draw the bounds and the halfway line.
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
The halfway line on a soccer field is _perpendicular_ to the sidelines.\
This rectangle has a perimeter of 800 pixels total, and it is 240 pixels long. How tall is it?   

Draw the bounds and the halfway line.

authored_hints.4-5_Artist_8_a:
The long sides are 240 pixels each.  That means that the 2 short sides must total:

**800 - 240 - 240 = 320**

What is **320/2** ?
authored_hints.4-5_Artist_8_b:
This image can be done 2 ways!  

-   Draw two rectangles that are **120** long and **160** tall, with an overlapping side

-   Draw one rectangle that is **240** long and **160** tall, then add a line in the middle.

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
Draw the right half of this image so that the design is symmetrical. 
The triangles are equilateral and have sides that are 50 pixels long.

authored_hints.4-5_Artist_9_a: When a triangle is an equilateral, all sides and all angles are the same.
authored_hints.4-5_Artist_9_b: You will need to draw three triangles of the same size. Don't forget to jump to your new position after each one.

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions:
"Me zombie artist. Me love drawing!"  

Help the zombie draw square glasses.  

The bridge between the glasses is 25 pixels shorter than the width of the squares, which is 100 pixels.
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
"Me zombie artist. Me love drawing!" 

Help the zombie draw square glasses.  

The bridge between the glasses is 25 pixels shorter than the width of the squares, which is 100 pixels.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Functions_1_a: The squares each have 100 pixel sides, that means that you will have to move forward 175 pixels before drawing your second square.
authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Functions_1_b: It is okay to draw overlapping lines to make your glasses.

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions:
Functions let you define new blocks! 

We've moved the blocks needed for drawing a square into a function called `draw a square`. This time, use the `draw a square` function to create the glasses. 

The squares are 75 pixels apart.
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
Functions let you define new blocks! 

We've moved the blocks needed for drawing a square into a function called `draw a square`. This time, use the `draw a square` function to create the glasses. 

The squares are 75 pixels apart.

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Functions_2_a:
Your program should:

-   Use function
-   Move forward 100 + 75 pixels
-   Use function

The squares are now 45 pixels apart.

We've renamed the `draw a square` function to `draw a hexagon`, but it's still giving us squares! Can you modify the `draw a hexagon` function to draw a hexagon with 50 pixel sides? 

Draw the image using the new function!
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
We've renamed the `draw a square` function to `draw a hexagon`, but it's still giving us squares!  

Can you modify the `draw a hexagon` function to draw a hexagon with 50 pixel sides? 

Draw the image using the new function!

authored_hints.2-3_Artist_Functions_11_a: You will need to change not only the number and length of sides within the function, but also the angle the artist turns between each side.

authored_hints.courseE_artist_functions_challenge1_a: If you call the function one more time, you can create the same design in the final corner. You can also `jump to` other positions or change the whole thing around however you want!

callouts.courseE_artist_functions_challenge1_call: Keep this program going by adding more code to the bottom.
If you don't like this design, change it to anything you want!

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions: Try this code to see how it works, then make the program your own!
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
Not only can you jump to some pre-set locations, like the corners of the canvas, you can also use a `jump to` command to get to absolutely any spot you like! Try this code to see how it works, then make the program your own!

[blockly block][0]

authored_hints.courseE_artist_functions_challenge1_a:
[blockly block][0]

This `jump to` block lets you move the zombie artist to any pixel on the grid, whenever you want. It works by moving him a number of pixels over to the right and a number of pixels down. This is always counted from the top left corner, which it means it doesn't matter where the zombie artist is _before_ the command is run!

[][1]

Check to see if there's a flower under the cloud, and only get nectar if there's a flower.\
Be careful, it can change!

More clouds!

Remember: Not all clouds hide the same thing!

More clouds!

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions: Now I just want to make honey. Some of these clouds might have honeycombs under them. Be sure to check each cloud!
Sometimes this cloud covers a flower, and sometimes it covers a honeycomb! Use the if/else block to collect nectar if it is a flower, else to make honey (because it is a honeycomb).

Sometimes this cloud covers a flower, and sometimes it covers a honeycomb! 

Use the `if/else` block to collect nectar only if it is a flower.\
Else, make honey (because it is a honeycomb).

authored_hints.courseF_bee_functions_challenge2_a:
If there is a path to the right, you should do the following:

-   Get any nectar or make any honey.
-   Turn right towards the side path.
-   Move to the end of the side path.
-   Turn right.

If you repeat the above actions twice, you will be ready to move back down the main path.

**Only click for another hint if you want to see the full solution!**

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions: Attach a block to the "when left arrow" block and press "Run". Move the paddle using the left arrow to reach the finish target.
Attach a block to the "when right arrow" and "when left arrow" blocks. Move the paddle to reach both finish targets.
Now try something similar with the "when up arrow" block. Move the paddle to the finish target at the top.
This time you need to add four blocks. Move the paddle to all four finish targets to complete this puzzle.
We're going to send a ball flying down towards the paddle. Attach a block to the "when ball hits paddle" block to ensure the ball reaches the finish target.
Now the finish target is on the top. You need to attach blocks to both of the "when ball hits" blocks to solve this puzzle.
Attach blocks to each of the "when" blocks. Bounce the ball until it hits the finish target.

There is now a goal at the top. Attach the "score point" and "score opponent point" blocks to the "when ball in goal" and "when ball misses paddle" blocks to make a game. See how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.

You can now attach blocks to the "when run" block. You have to attach the new "launch new ball" block in more than one place. Also, try changing the scene or the speed of the paddle and the ball and see how many points you can score before your opponent scores twice.
Create your own Bounce game. You can change all the visuals and the rules. When you're done, click Finish to let friends try your game on their phones.

Something should happen when you get enough points or when you run out of points. Add some code to the `win game` and `lose game` functions to make the game work the way it should. 
Click the hints for ideas!
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
_The **squirrels** are terrified to see that a **dinosaur** has come to town! Can the brave **knight** keep them all from panicking?_

Rules:

1.  _Touching the squirrels scores you points._
2.  _Touching the dinosaur takes many points away._

Here is a different kind of game that has already been started for you! Play it to see how it works. 

Something should happen when you get enough points or when you run out of points. Add some code to the `win game` and `lose game` functions to make the game work the way it should. 
Click the hints for ideas!

authored_hints.courseE_playLab_challenge1_a:
Here are some things you could do when the player wins the game:

-   Make the dinosaur vanish.
-   Stop the squirrels.
-   Make the squirrels and knight happy.
-   Set a new background.
-   Make the knight thank the player for helping.
-   Make all of the actors vanish and show a "You Win!" message.
authored_hints.courseE_playLab_challenge1_b:
Here are some things you could do when the player loses the game:

-   Make the knight vanish.
-   Make the squirrels sad.
-   Make the dinosaur say something.
-   Set a new background.
-   Make all of the actors vanish and show a "Game Over" message.

callouts.courseC_PlayLab_events_challenge1_1: This block lets you move actors to different parts of the game space.

authored_hints.4-5_Artist_Patterns_5_a:
Now, when the artist finished each diamond, he's facing the opposite direction from where he needs to be to start the next one.  

How many degrees does he need to be turned to set himself straight?

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions: How many times do you need to repeat this block to draw the full grid of diamonds?
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions: How many times do you need to repeat this block to draw the full grid of diamonds?

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions: Let's modify the code from the last puzzle to make this more complex pattern. Notice how the diamonds overlap now, try changing the first "jump backwards" from 100 to 50 (half as far) - now how far should the artist go in the second "jump backwards"?
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions: Let's modify the code from the last puzzle to make this more complex pattern. Notice how the diamonds overlap now, try changing the first "jump backwards" from 100 to 50 (half as far) - now how far should the artist go in the second "jump backwards"?

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions: Use a loop to draw this hexagon with 40 pixel sides and 60 degree angles.
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions: Use a loop to draw this hexagon with 40 pixel sides and 60 degree angles.

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions:
Now repeat this code 3 times and draw the whole row. 

Each hexagon is 80 pixels wide from the furthest points left to right.
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
Now repeat this code 3 times and draw the whole row. 

Each hexagon is 80 pixels wide from the furthest points left to right.

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions: Let's loop this code to draw two rows of hexagons. Notice how our second row is shifted to the right.
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
Let's loop this code to draw two rows of hexagons. 

Notice how our second row is shifted to the right.

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions:
This code draws two rows of hexagons - loop the whole thing 4 times to draw the whole honeycomb. 

You'll need to jump back 120 pixels in your outermost loop to make sure the artist doesn't draw off the screen.
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
This code draws two rows of hexagons - loop the whole thing 4 times to draw the whole honeycomb. 

You'll need to jump back 120 pixels in your outermost loop to make sure the artist doesn't draw off the screen.

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions: How many times do you need to loop this to draw a half circle?
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions: How many times do you need to loop this to draw a half circle?

authored_hints.4-5_Artist_Patterns_11_a: If there are 360 degrees in a circle and each loop turns 3 degrees, how many times would you need to loop draw half of a full circle?

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions:
If you create another loop like this one, but turn left instead of right, what happens? 

Can you repeat all of that to draw this wave?
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
If you create another loop like this one, but turn left instead of right, what happens? 

Can you repeat all of that to draw this wave?

https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.short_instructions:
Now let's loop that whole thing four times to create this picture frame. Watch out for the corners - you can't just turn 90 degrees! 

If looping a 3 degree turn 60 times makes a half circle, which of these blocks of code will make an additional quarter circle for the corners?
https://studio.code.org/s/course3/stage/.long_instructions:
Now let's loop that whole thing four times to create this picture frame. Watch out for the corners - you can't just turn 90 degrees!
